Hi Oliver,

Yes, it's great to have cluster functionality in there!

Can yo=
u elaborate a little bit on what exactly didn't work when you tried
to run =
your experiments with ES-HyperNEAT? Other people might run into the
same
pr=
oblems so trying to figure out exactly what the problem was could be
helpfu=
l.

Did you ever try to implement the simple maze navigation task from the =
same
paper?

Best,
Sebastian

On Wed, Mar 18, 2015 at 3:59 AM, Oliver Colem=
an oliver.coleman@...
[neat] <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:

>
>
> Hi =
Ken,
>
> Yes, I've tested and verified all of these variants and extensions=
 apart
> from ES-HyperNEAT. I've just added a note to the readme about this=
 last one:
>
> NOTE: A lot of time was spent checking every aspect of the E=
S-HyperNEAT
> implementation however it was not possible to reproduce the e=
xperiments in
> Risi S. and Stanley K.O. (2012) An Enhanced Hypercube-Based=
 Encoding for
> Evolving the Placement, Density and Connectivity of Neurons=
, Artificial
> Life, MIT Press, thus the implementation should be assumed t=
o be be not
> working. Feel free to try it out and let me know how you go! =
:)
>
> Cheers,
> Oliver
>
>
> T: 0421 972 953 | E: oliver.coleman@...=
 | W: http://ojcoleman.com

xas.edu [neat] <
> neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
>>
>>
>> Hi Oliver, thank=
s for your work on AHNI, cluster compatibility is very
>> useful.  As with =
other areas of machine learning, neuroevolution is likely
>> to benefit fro=
m massive and increasing computational power, so it's good if
>> our softwa=
re can take advantage of it.
>>
>> By the way, I see notes in your github f=
or support of all kinds of
>> variants as well, such as ES-HyperNEAT, LEO, =
NSGA-II, and novelty search.
>> Are all those really working well and valid=
ated?  If so I'd add mention of
>> them to my software links collection (
>=
> http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software).  I'm also planning to
>> over=
haul that list because it's become so large and disorganized that new
>> pe=
ople coming in can't figure out which package they should really be
>> choo=
sing.  My plan is to make it a lot more helpful in pointing people to
>> wh=
at they need.  But anyway AHNI deserves to be featured prominently.
>>
>> B=
est,
>>
>> ken
>>
>

nsions apart from ES-HyperNEAT. I've just added a note to the readme ab=

<p>Hi Oliver, thanks for your work on AHNI, cluster compatibility is very u=
seful.=C2=A0 As with other areas of machine learning, neuroevolution is lik=
ely to benefit from massive and increasing computational power, so it's=
 good if our software can take advantage of it.=C2=A0 <br><br>By the way, I=
 see notes in your github for support of all kinds of variants as well, suc=
h as ES-HyperNEAT, LEO, NSGA-II, and novelty search.=C2=A0 Are all those re=
ally working well and validated?=C2=A0 If so I'd add mention of them to=
 my software links collection (<a href=3D"http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#=
software" target=3D"_blank">http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software</a>).=
=C2=A0 I'm also planning to overhaul that list because it's become =
so large and disorganized that new people coming in can't figure out wh=
ich package they should really be choosing.=C2=A0 My plan is to make it a l=
ot more helpful in pointing people to what they need.=C2=A0 But anyway AHNI=
 deserves to be featured prominently.<br><br>Best,<br><br>ken=C2=A0</p>
